name: title_series
text: Urban Policy and Built Environment Scorecard 2020

name: access_profile_text
text: (above) City estimates for percentage of population with access to amenities within 500 metres (m) can be compared with the performance of other cities in our global study.

name: quality_qualifier
text: ¹ Policy quality rating rewards specific, measurable policies aligned with consensus evidence on healthy cities

name: policy2_text1
text: Transport and planning combined in one government department?

name: policy2_text2
text: Metropolitan urban policy specifies health-focused actions?

name: policy2_text3
text: Metropolitan transport policy specifies health-focused actions?

name: policy2_text4
text: Health Impact Assessment incorporated into urban/transport policy or legislation?

name: policy2_text5
text: Information on government expenditure on infrastructure for different transport modes?

name: policy2_text6
text: Air pollution policies related to both transport and land use planning

name: walkability_description
text: Walkable neighbourhoods underpin a liveable city, providing opportunities for healthy sustainable lifestyles.  Walkability encompasses accessibility of services and amenities and is influenced by policies determining land use mix and population density, as well as street connectivity.

name: policy_Checklist_text3
text: Parking restrictions to discourage car use

name: pt_description
text: Small bit of explanatory text on why PT is important for health and sustainability. Sentence about what policies determine PT access (ie. Indicators below).

name: policy_PT_text1
text: Requirements for public transport access to employment and infrastructure

name: policy_PT_text2
text: Requirements for distribution of employment across the city

name: policy_PT_text3
text: Minimum requirements for public transport access

name: policy_POS_text1
